author: HLB's Liver Cancer Drug Listed as First-line Treatment in ESMO Guidelines, "Strongly Recomm...
title: HLB's Liver Cancer Drug Listed as First-line Treatment in ESMO Guidelines, "Strongly Recomm...
text:
It is highly unusual for a drug that has not yet received regulatory approval to be recommended for prescription in clinical settings.
The guideline classifies the clinical evidence supporting Rivoceranib + Camrelizumab as â€œLevel of Evidence I,â€ the highest rating. It strongly recommends this combination as a first-line treatment for liver cancer patients with relatively preserved liver function.
Additionally, the guideline also recommends other first-line therapies, including Bevacizumab + Atezolizumab and Durvalumab + Tremelimumab. However, it specifies that patients with a history or risk of gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding undergoing Bevacizumab-based therapy must undergo screening procedures beforehand. This reflects the necessity of conducting endoscopic examinations before prescribing Bevacizumab due to its high risk of causing GI bleeding.
Han Yong-hae, chief technology officer of HLB Group, stated â€œWith regulatory approval imminent, ESMOâ€™s strong recommendation for Rivoceranib + Camrelizumab as a first-line liver cancer treatment signifies that HLBâ€™s therapy has been internationally recognized as a standard treatment. This is a positive signal not only for obtaining EMA and FDA approvals but also for its inclusion in the NCCN guidelines.â€

author: Jay Rincher
title: WASPâ€™s Clay 3D Printing Tech Enables Climate Cooling Designs
text:
For several years, Italian 3D printer manufacturer
WASP has made its printers available on campuses across the world, giving students access to the same tools as world-class architectural firms. Now, embrace of campus life by WASP has born sweet fruit.
For over two years, the
Bartlett School of Architecture at University College London (UCL) has hosted a Delta WASP 40100 Clay in its labs, utilized by students of the Design for Manufacture faculty for research and the execution of their thesis projects. Under expert guidance, students gained hands-on experience with the printers, contributing to advancements in the AM field. In 2024, students in the Additive Manufacturing Group, led by tutor Arthur Prior, completed their Masterâ€™s degrees and published their thesis projects.
Highlighted Projects
Silicone 3D Printing with a Multi-Nozzle Extrusion System by Tom Younger, Tianyang Li, Qinyuan Zheng â€“ Tutor: Arthur Prior
Tom Younger, Tianyang Li, and Qinyuan Zheng developed a multi-nozzle 3D printing extrusion system. Their project aimed to create silicone auxetic tiles for a pneumatic shading system. These lightweight tiles form a â€˜breathingâ€™ window frame structure, adjusting light entry by expanding and contracting. The teamâ€™s innovation relies on siliconeâ€™s elasticity and durability to move away from traditional architectural designs by offering a new approach to balancing shading and light transmission in buildings without energy-intensive equipment.
TerraMound â€“ 3D Printed Cooling Systems in Ceramic, By Rameshwari Jonnalagedda â€“ Tutor: Arthur Prior
Rameshwari Jonnalageddaâ€™s TerraMound project features ceramic 3D printing to create cooling systems inspired by termite mounds. The design features minimal surface geometries, maximizing cooling and airflow. A desktop fan prototype draws air through a porous ceramic body, using evaporative cooling to enhance efficiency. This project envisions buildings with adaptive, dynamic cooling systems that integrate seamlessly with natural processes.
Ceram-Screens â€“ A Climate Responsive 3D Printed Parametric FaÃ§ade By Monisha Sridhara â€“ Tutors: Nikoletta Karastathi, Arthur Prior
Monisha Sridharaâ€™s Ceram-Screens project revitalizes the traditional Jaali screens found in Indian architecture. These screens reduce solar glare and improve ventilation by utilizing ceramic 3D printing for customization and replicability. The modules, shaped like frustum cones, redirect wind and light while maintaining privacy. This project seeks to re-popularize traditional craftsmanship through the use of 21st century innovation.
Itâ€™s fascinating to see each of these young designers put their ingenuity towards design that responds to
our increasingly heating planet. Each of these projects may just end up as one small piece of the puzzle we need to solve to reduce the impact of climate change.
Lithoz
Himed and Lithoz Launch Center for Bioceramics 3D Printing
Himed, a US manufacturer of bioceramic materials, and ceramics 3D printing leader Lithoz have announced a joint venture meant to combine their respective areas of expertiseâ€”the Bioceramics Center of Excellence...
New IN-VISION Light Engine with Multiple Exposures Presents Exciting Opportunities for 3D Printing
Just a few companies produce the light engines that power vat polymerization and powder bed fusion 3D printers. Among them is IN-VISION, an Austrian company that specializes in using Texas...
3DPOD Episode 197: Ceramics 3D Printing with Johannes Homa, Lithoz CEO
Lithoz is a pioneer in the 3D printing of technical ceramics, initially using a ceramic-loaded stereolithography process and later adopting multiple technologies. Johannes Homa, a researcher turned entrepreneur, discusses his...

author: MartÃ­n del Toro
title: Recupera tus amadas sandalias u ojotas manchadas con un solo ingrediente, y dÃ©jalas listas para el verano
text: Truco de limpieza Recupera tus amadas sandalias u ojotas manchadas con un solo ingrediente, y dÃ©jalas listas para el veranoLas sandalias una vez pasado el verano suelen ser guardadas sin una buena limpieza y cuando debemos utilizarlas nuevamente quitar la capa de suciedad puede ser complejo. Con la llegada del verano vuelven tambiÃ©n las [sandalias](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandalia) y muchas veces cuando ha pasado mucho tiempo sin que las hayamos utilizado estas pueden verse cubiertas de una capa de suciedad que es difÃ­cil de remover. Hoy te contamos cuÃ¡l es el truco de limpieza definitivo que con tan solo el detergente de tu cocina va a ayudarte a que tus sandalias luzcan como nuevas y puedas calzar de manera cÃ³moda y fresca en este verano. En el verano el calzado cÃ³modo y fresco como el de las sandalias es fundamental debido a que los calores son realmente altos y por ello los zapatos cerrados no son una buena opciÃ³n. Las sandalias una vez pasado el verano suelen ser guardadas sin una buena limpieza y cuando debemos utilizarlas nuevamente quitar la capa de suciedad puede ser complejo. Este truco de limpieza ademÃ¡s de ser sumamente funcional es realmente econÃ³mico ya que tan solo vamos a necesitar como ingrediente del tan afamado [detergente](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%C3%ADquido_lavavajillas) que seguramente tenemos en la cocina. Â¿CÃ³mo dejar tus sandalias como nuevas con este truco de limpieza y un poco de detergente? Es importante que previo aplicar el detergente en nuestras sandalias podamos entender que el truco de limpieza reside en diluir el detergente con un poco de agua dentro de un difusor y impregnar la tela de las sandalias con este lÃ­quido esperando que se seque por completo. Una vez que se hayan secado las sandalias vamos a tomar un cepillo y vamos a poner las bajo el agua y refregar hasta que toda la suciedad comience a salir por completo. El detergente posee propiedades poderosas que no solo son Ãºtiles para nuestra cocina nuestros muebles sino que tambiÃ©n puede ser muy funcionales para algunas telas, como por ejemplo las de las sandalias. Este truco de limpieza ademÃ¡s de ser muy sencillo es muy econÃ³mico y va a darte grandes resultados permitiÃ©ndote restaurar de manera muy evidente la calidad integral de tus sandalias. Un aspecto a tener en cuenta es que cuando utilizamos el detergente como truco de limpieza para limpiar las sandalias es importante que cuando esto se sequen lo hagan lejos del sol ya que el sol puede afectar las propiedades de la tela de las sandalias y puede terminar daÃ±ando su superficie y por ende es importante tener este aspecto en cuenta si vamos a realizar este conocido y efectivo truco de limpieza.

author: GearTechnica
title: Hot Deal: Get A Pair Of EcoFlow 100W Solar Panels For $150
text:
Hot Deal: Get A Pair Of EcoFlow 100W Solar Panels For $150
daily news updates from CleanTechnicaon email. Or follow us on Google News!
One of the biggest talking points for going solar has been the promise of â€œfree electricity,â€ which was a bit of a stretch, considering that the initial outlay for solar panels used to be quite hefty. However, given the long effective life that solar panels generally have (20+ years), it was certainly possible for them to produce enough electricity over the years to cover the relatively high cost then, and to continue providing clean and â€œfreeâ€ electricity for a long time. And now, with the dropping cost of solar panels of all shapes and sizes, from the small and lightweight or thin film folding panels to the larger â€˜standardâ€™ rooftop panels, itâ€™s possible to get in on the renewable energy revolution with an even lower buy-in.
If youâ€™ve been sitting on the proverbial fence about acquiring the equipment to grab some solar electrons of your own, whether you want to offset some of your electricity costs or you want ensure that the power is still flowing at your home in the event of a blackout or emergency, it might behoove you to take a close look at this hot deal on solar panels from
EcoFlow.
A pair of 100W solar panels from EcoFlow, which normally sells for about $250,
is currently on sale for $149 on Amazon, and with the promise of producing up to 500 Wh / 45 Ah of electricity per day, they could be the right choice for building a decent solar array for a variety of applications. They are dirt-, dust-, and waterproof (IP68), have pre-drilled mounting holes, and weigh about 13.6 pounds per pair, so installing them on a rack for the rooftop of an RV, boat, tiny house, shed, cabin, or as a ground-mounted system for remote or home backup power wonâ€™t require a structural engineer, and at their current sale price are affordable enough to buy in multiples for a good-sized array. And they pair well with EcoFlow portable power stations, so storing your harvested electrons will be easy-peasy.

author: @httweets
title: Chandigarh colder than Manali, Shimla despite sunny afternoon
text:
Chandigarh colder than Manali, Shimla despite sunny afternoon
At 13.2Â°C, the maximum temperature of the city was lower than Manali where the maximum temperature was 14.8Â°C
Though the maximum temperature rose slightly due to the sunny conditions in the afternoon, Chandigarh was colder than hill stations such as Manali and Shimla on Thursday, as per the India Meteorological Department (IMD).
The temperatures are likely to drop further during the weekend with rain being predicted for Sunday and Monday.
At 13.2Â°C, the maximum temperature of the city was lower than Manali where the maximum temperature was 14.8Â°C. Even Shimla was much warmer at 17.2Â°C and Dharamshala at 22.9Â°C.
This comes even as maximum temperature of the city rose from 11.3Â°C on Wednesday. As Thursdayâ€™s day temperature was five degrees below normal, it was categorised as a cold day. A cold day is declared when the maximum temperature goes over 4.5 degrees below normal and minimum temperature drops below 10Â°C.
The minimum temperature fell from 8.7Â°C on Wednesday to 8.6Â°C on Thursday, still 1.4 degrees above normal. While many hill stations were colder at night, the city was still colder than Shimla where the minimum temperature on Thursday was 9.6Â°C.
Speaking about this, IMD Chandigarh director Surender Paul said, â€œThis has to do with fog which blocks sunlight in the plains. However, we see brighter sunlight in the hills which is why sometimes the maximum temperature of Chandigarh sometimes drops lower than hill stations like Shimla and Dharamshala.â€
Flights delayed
Dense fog was recorded in the city on Thursday morning, with visibility going down to 150 metres around 5:30 am on Thursday. As per IMD, visibility between 50 metres and 200 metres is considered dense fog. Chances of dense fog will continue on Friday especially in the morning.
A total of 10 flights, including four arrivals, were delayed at Chandigarh International Airport on Thursday due to fog. This included the Indigo flight 6E262 from Srinagar, which arrived at 3.20 pm against the scheduled time of 1 pm. Another Indigo flight, 6E2196, from Delhi, landed at Chandigarh airport at 4.35 pm against the scheduled time of 4.10 pm. Air India flight AI2659 landed here at 5:56 pm instead of its scheduled time of 5.15 pm. Indigo flight 6E5178, from Mumbai, which was scheduled to land at 6.15 pm, arrived at 6.59 pm. Indigo flight 6E328 to Bengaluru departed at 11.22 am against the scheduled time of 10.50 am. The Indigo flight to Srinagar 6E6352 took off for Srinagar at 4.08 pm instead of its scheduled time of 2.10 pm. The Indigo flight 6E7721 to Dharamshala departed at 2.46 pm against the scheduled time of 2.20 pm. Air India flight AI2660 departed for Mumbai at 6.55 pm against the scheduled time of 3.10 pm. The Indigo flight for Mumbai 6E6203 departed at 5.27pm against the scheduled time of 4.40 pm. Indigo flight 6E2113 took off for Delhi at 7.47 pm against the scheduled time of 6.45 pm.
